importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the news article indicates the current status of food supply operations in Gaza, highlighting the ongoing humanitarian crisis and the urgency of expanding aid delivery.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The article states that current food supplies are sufficient for half a million people for two weeks, indicating the short-term sustainability of aid and the risk of supply shortages if the ceasefire fails.

keyTakeAways: Food supplies to Gaza are significantly below the UN World Food Programme's daily target of 2,000 tonnes.
Only two Israeli-controlled crossings—Karem Abu Salem and al-Karara—are currently operational, severely limiting aid access.
The WFP now operates 26 food distribution points in Gaza, up from five, but still far short of the 145 needed to cover the entire territory.
Humanitarian aid has not reached northern Gaza due to restrictions, including the closure of the Rafah border crossing.
Hamas has pledged to hand over the remains of 28 captives, having delivered 13 so far, which is a key condition for reopening crossings and enabling aid access.
WFP is urging international actors and Israel to open all border crossings to allow full-scale humanitarian access.
The US-brokered ceasefire under Donald Trump is critical for sustaining the humanitarian effort and preventing famine.
Residents in Gaza are storing food due to fear of future supply disruptions, indicating deep insecurity about the ceasefire’s longevity.

namedEntities.name: UN World Food Programme (WFP)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A United Nations agency responsible for coordinating international humanitarian food aid.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The WFP is central to the article as it reports on the status and shortfall of food deliveries to Gaza, calling for expanded crossings and increased aid access.

namedEntities.name: Gaza Strip
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A Palestinian territory under Israeli control, currently devastated by conflict and facing severe humanitarian shortages.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Gaza Strip is the primary location of the food supply crisis, with the article detailing the scale of aid delivery and the lack of access to key areas like the north.

namedEntities.name: Karem Abu Salem
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An Israeli-controlled border crossing into Gaza, currently operational.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: One of the two functioning crossings into Gaza, through which approximately 750 metric tonnes of food enter daily.

namedEntities.name: al-Karara (Kissufim)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An Israeli-controlled border crossing into Gaza, currently operational.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The second functioning crossing into Gaza, used to deliver food supplies to the central region of the Strip.

namedEntities.name: Rafah border crossing
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A crossing between Gaza and Egypt, currently closed.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The closure of Rafah limits humanitarian access and is dependent on Hamas’s return of captives' remains, which is a key political condition.

namedEntities.name: Salah al-Din Street
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A major north-south road in Gaza, currently blocked to WFP convoys.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The WFP has been denied access to use this route, preventing aid delivery to northern Gaza and limiting aid reach.

namedEntities.name: Donald Trump
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Former US President, who brokered a ceasefire in Gaza and proposed a 20-point plan for ending the war.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: His role as a mediator in the ceasefire and his call for full aid delivery is central to the article’s argument about sustaining humanitarian access.

namedEntities.name: Benjamin Netanyahu
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Israeli Prime Minister, who stated the Rafah crossing remains closed until Hamas hands over captives’ bodies.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: His position on the Rafah crossing reflects Israeli government policy constraints on humanitarian access, directly affecting aid delivery.

namedEntities.name: Hamas
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A Palestinian political and militant group, responsible for governing parts of Gaza and holding captives.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Hamas has committed to return the bodies of Israeli captives, which is a key condition for reopening crossings and enabling humanitarian access.

namedEntities.name: Qassam Brigades
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A militant wing of Hamas, responsible for announcing the return of captives’ remains.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Qassam Brigades confirmed the return of two Israeli captives’ bodies, signaling progress on a key condition for aid access.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The UN World Food Programme reports that food supplies to Gaza are still far below the daily target of 2,000 tonnes, with only two border crossings—Karem Abu Salem and al-Karara—currently open. Despite an increase in distribution points from five to 26, the WFP says access to northern Gaza remains severely limited due to the closure of the Rafah crossing and the lack of access to Salah al-Din Street. The US-brokered ceasefire, supported by Donald Trump’s 20-point plan, is crucial to sustaining aid, but humanitarian access depends on Hamas fulfilling its promise to return the bodies of deceased captives. As of now, only 750 metric tonnes of food enter Gaza daily, and residents are storing supplies due to fear of future disruptions, with current supplies sufficient for half a million people for two weeks.
title: WFP says food supplies to Gaza below targets, urges more crossings to open
